description:
The Bourbon virus is a newly discovered tick-borne virus that was first identified in 2014 in Bourbon County, Kansas, United States. It is a member of the Thogotovirus genus within the Orthomyxoviridae family, which also includes the influenza viruses.

The Bourbon virus is a single-stranded, negative-sense RNA virus with a segmented genome. It is primarily transmitted to humans through the bite of infected ticks, particularly the Lone Star tick (Amblyomma americanum). The virus can cause a severe febrile illness in humans, with symptoms that may include fever, fatigue, headache, muscle and joint pain, nausea, and vomiting.

While the exact mechanisms of pathogenesis are still under investigation, the Bourbon virus is believed to primarily target and replicate within human immune cells, such as lymphocytes and monocytes. This can lead to a dysregulation of the immune response and potentially life-threatening complications, including multi-organ failure and neurological manifestations.

Currently, there is no specific treatment or vaccine for Bourbon virus infection, and management of the disease relies on supportive care and the management of symptoms. Ongoing research is focused on better understanding the epidemiology, transmission dynamics, and potential therapeutic interventions for this emerging viral pathogen.
